<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[617, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 902, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 360, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 699, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 890, 605]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 712, 904, 839]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 867, 726, 883]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 73, 737, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 99, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 103, 707, 122]]<|/det|>
1 In this experiment, you will investigate a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 135, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 500, 152]]<|/det|>
(a) • Connect the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 165, 833, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 380, 532, 397]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 411, 468, 427]]<|/det|>
• Ensure that the switch S is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 441, 185, 458]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 441, 918, 473]]<|/det|>
• Slide the LDR leads into the tube until the front of the LDR is just level with the open end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 488, 918, 518]]<|/det|>
• With the LDR in this position, attach a piece of adhesive tape to the leads as a marker at the other end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 535, 880, 551]]<|/det|>
• Slide the tube until the LDR is approximately half-way along it, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 562, 720, 661]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 680, 532, 696]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) Change \(x\) by moving the LDR to a new position inside the tube, with \(x\) in the range 4 cm to 18 cm. Record \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 576, 138]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 147, 691, 170]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\sqrt{I}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 570, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 600, 144, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 600, 185, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 596, 653, 618]]<|/det|>
(c) (i) Plot a graph of \(\sqrt{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 188, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 630, 458, 647]]<|/det|>
(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 661, 191, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 660, 608, 677]]<|/det|>
(iii) Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 829, 918, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 719, 91]]<|/det|>
(d) It is suggested that the quantities \(I\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 100, 551, 123]]<|/det|>
\[
\sqrt{I}=a x+b
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 136, 400, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 167, 672, 199]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in (c)(iii), determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\). Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 287, 918, 305]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& a= . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . \\
& b= . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 336, 870, 353]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<form>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 90]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 99, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 103, 732, 121]]<|/det|>
2 In this experiment, you will investigate the elastic properties of rubber cord.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 136, 185, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 135, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
(a) (i) You are provided with a wire with a clip and two slotted masses attached, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 180, 737, 348]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 363, 532, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 394, 905, 411]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of the two slotted masses is \(B\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 425, 388, 440]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 562, 918, 581]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
B=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 596, 188, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 594, 814, 612]]<|/det|>
(ii) Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(B\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 797, 918, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = \(\%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 185, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 833, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) You are provided with two lengths of rubber cord. Select the longer cord.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 106, 477, 122]]<|/det|>
· The diameter of the cord is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 136, 424, 153]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 180, 580, 197]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
d=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 180, 920, 197]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 188, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 214, 918, 246]]<|/det|>
(ii) · Suspend the clip, wire and masses using the longer cord secured in the two clips, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 255, 841, 648]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 660, 592, 677]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 691, 781, 708]]<|/det|>
· The length of cord between the two clips is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 722, 424, 738]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 765, 580, 782]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
L=
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 191, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
• Keeping the cord vertical, rotate the lower clip through approximately \(180^{\circ}\) and release the clip. The clip will rotate with a small number of oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 121, 787, 139]]<|/det|>
• Take measurements to determine the period \(T\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 290, 918, 308]]<|/det|>
<form>T = \(\mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 322, 144, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 322, 580, 339]]<|/det|>
(c) Using the shorter length of rubber cord, repeat (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 420, 918, 437]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d =\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 585, 918, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>T = \(\mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 651, 91]]<|/det|>
(d) It is suggested that the relationship between \(T, B, L\) and \(d\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 101, 537, 131]]<|/det|>
\[
T^{2}=\frac{B^{2} L}{k d^{4}}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 140, 339, 156]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 172, 185, 189]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 170, 549, 189]]<|/det|>
(i) Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 370, 904, 388]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k=\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 402, 904, 420]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k=\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 415, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 448, 188, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 447, 851, 465]]<|/det|>
(ii) Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 572, 144, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 570, 750, 588]]<|/det|>
(e) It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(20 \%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 602, 828, 620]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in (d).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 185, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 908, 91]]<|/det|>
(f) (i) Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
For any uncertainties in measurement that you describe, you should state the quantity being measured and a reason for the uncertainty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 154, 207, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<label>2</label>

<label>3</label>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 415, 144, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 415, 918, 447]]<|/det|>
(ii) Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures.
